items.title: Supporting multi valued categorical feature for Kprototypes
items.body:
## Expected Behavior
Suppose I have a data-set which contains a mix of numerical and categorical features.
Suppose I have a categorical feature which is multi valued.
For example , the feature may be movie_genre which may take multiple values like {comedy, action, drama, thriller horror}.
When the encoding is done for such categorical feature, the code doesn't consider  the overlap 
between the multi valued categorical features.
For example , if a data point has genre- {action, drama}
and another data point has genre-{action, thriller}, the jaccard similarity should be taken into account
## Actual Behavior
The encoding for multivalued categorical features is done such that it considers the feature {action, thriller} separate to {thriller, action}

## Steps to Reproduce the Problem
Take any data having multi valued categorical feature and run the k-prototypes algo.
You will see that in the encoding step the categorical attributes like {action, thriller}
and {thriller, action} have been labelled differently. They are not considered same or their jaccard similarity is not taken into account

  1.
  1.

items.title: Consistency of categorical encoding of missing values
items.body:
If the same categorical values goes across multiple dimensions, there is no consistency in the mapping.

E.g.
cols = ["origin", "Middle name", "Dog's name"]
A = ["USA", "None", "None"] can be mapped 
A = [1,0,1]

It might be convenient to have consistency, so one could ask, how many non_null values is in A after the encoding. This could be used for indexing and thus speed up calculation.

items.title: Why does cluster init ever fail with "Clustering algorithm could not initialize." when init=random?
items.body:
Assuming that n_clusters is less than the number of rows in the dataset we are inputting, why would it ever be the case that random initialization would fail? 

I'm pretty sure I am missing something because the code seems built to expect 'random' initialization to sometimes fail. Intuitively, I would think that random init should be as simple as picking [n_clusters] points from the data set at random and using them as initial centroids, so the initialization step should never fail as long as the number of points is greater than n_clusters. What am I missing? Thanks!

I'm trying to extract the cluster centroids after calling km.fit on my data. The actual fitting procedure completes without any problems, but when I try to get the centroids I get the following error:

```
Init: initializing centroids

    outputs = ufunc(*inputs)
KeyError: 255
```
The weird thing though is that this error only occurs if I pass an ndarray into KModes with the `init` keyword. The docs say that this is supported, but apparently it's not. The error appears regardless of the numbers in the array, even if they're the centroids that I just got from fitting (I tried random initialization too)! If I just use `init='Huang'` or `init='Cao'`, everything executes cleanly and I can extract the centroids just fine. When I check the underlying km._enc_cluster_centroids attribute, this is well-defined and returns an ndarray, but I don't know how to interpret these numbers. It seems like the error lies in however the _enc_cluster_centroid is decoded (in the decode_centroids function), but I don't understand what's happening there as the helper functions are split up over multiple files.

The code snippet that is generating this error is
```python
if LOAD_PREVIOUS_CENTROIDS:
    with open('./centroids.pickle', mode='rb') as fo:
        centroid_init = pickle.load(fo)
        #centroid_init = np.random.randint(15, size=(15,8))
else:
    centroid_init = 'Huang'

            init=centroid_init,
            n_init=1,
            verbose=1)
c = kp.fit_predict(id_df.values)
print('Done fitting')
centroid_init = kp.cluster_centroids_
with open('./centroids.pickle', mode='wb') as fo:
    pickle.dump(centroid_init, fo)
```
So you can see that if I were to run this, the centroids from the fit would essentially get plugged back in as initialization, and this still fails.

Any ideas? I'm running python 3.7, with kmodes version 0.9, scikit-learn version 0.19.2, numpy version 1.15.4., scipy version 1.1.0

items.title: Parallel implementation
items.body:
Hello again,

The K-Prototypes algorithm continues to intrigue me, so I played around with it some more. I did the Cython implementation before, as discussed in #57, but the changes required for that were so far-reaching I can imagine merging the back into this repository is challenging.

In the meantime, I implemented both K-Modes and K-Prototypes in a parallel fashion, basically copying the strategy applied in scikit-learn, namely doing multiple runs with different initializations in parallel using joblib.
Minimal code changes are required to accomplish this, so it might make a better initial candidate to improve performance. Most changes are related to the way the algorithms deal with random variables, as this becomes a little more difficult to keep reproducible when adding threading into the mix.

I did some testing on a dataset that I unfortunately cannot share, the results of which are in this gist:
https://gist.github.com/rphes/48569eb0c929d33deef18c9de0d96aa8

Interesting observations are that K-Prototypes benefits from multithreading whereas K-Modes really does not. I think this might be due to the very low complexity of the K-Modes algorithm, making it memory-bound. Threading therefore only introduces additional overhead due to the forking process and resource contention between threads.
K-Prototypes performs some actual computations, so it is less affected by this, but still we see performance increase level off at 4 cores, presumable for the same reason.

Now, if you'd like to incorporate this stuff, I'm more than happy to submit a PR, with a parallel version of K-Prototypes, or both algorithms with added tests and documentation. The only caveat is that users need to consider whether their use-case is actually going to see performance increase when throwing more cores at it, as my example shows.
The API is completely backwards compatible, so that should not be an issue.

Check out the code here:
https://github.com/rphes/kmodes/tree/parallel
and let me know what you think!

items.title: Summed dissimilarity measure in Cao's method
items.body:
## TL;DR: No need to read this issue - I realise I made a mistake ### Hello, and apologies for the long issue... My name is Henry Wilde and I am a PhD student at Cardiff University. I am currently working on a research project involving the k-modes and k-prototypes algorithms and have been using this implementation of the algorithms to compute my results. In particular, I have been looking at the initialisation processes to the k-modes algorithm. Whilst reading Cao's original [paper](https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/1955/c6801bca5e95a44e70ce14180f00fd3e55b8.pdf) alongside the source code for this implementation, I believe that I have found an error in the implementation of Cao's method (and potentially Huang's as well) due to the wrong dissimilarity measure being used. I have a working implementation locally, and hope it would be alright to open a pull request for these changes. I've detailed where I believe the issue to be below, and have given a small working example to highlight the difference. The paper, and other papers (such as [Huang's](http://arbor.ee.ntu.edu.tw/~chyun/dmpaper/huanet98.pdf)), define the standard dissimilarity measure between two points to be the number of attributes where the two points are not equal. Then, separately, the summed dissimilarity of a point in the dataset is the sum of all the pairwise dissimilarities between the point of interest and all other points in the dataset. There are definitions for these two measures and for the average density of a point [here](https://drive.google.com/open?id=16SfhcuxGmCbSo70ek2NPZYe3lwZ322BZ). In this implementation, I believe that the summed dissimilarity measure is used where the pairwise dissimilarity measure should be used (a full statement of the algorithm is given [here](https://drive.google.com/open?id=1xnzp-mZh-MZwKdXi_omtIwKVTqnrGz0v)), and that is leading to incorrect initialisations. ### A small example below highlights this: Consider the following dataset with N=10 elements described by m=5 attributes: - Buying price - Maintenance costs - No. doors - No. passengers - No. wheels The first two attributes take values from L, M, H, V standing for low, medium, high, and very high, respectively. The other three attributes are integer variables and are considered to be categorical.
Buying price Maintenance costs No. doors No. passengers No. wheels
0 H M 2 2 4
1 L M 0 1 2
2 V H 2 3 8
3 H L 4 5 4
4 M M 2 5 4
5 M L 2 4 4
6 V H 4 5 4
7 L V 2 4 4
8 H M 0 2 2
9 H M 4 7 4
Suppose we wish to cluster this dataset into 3 parts. To initialise this dataset for clustering with the k-modes algorithm by Cao's method, we begin by finding the average density of each point in our set. This is given in the last column of the following table:
Buying price Maintenance costs No. doors No. passengers No. wheels Density
0 H M 2 2 4 0.46
1 L M 0 1 2 0.24
2 V H 2 3 8 0.22
3 H L 4 5 4 0.38
4 M M 2 5 4 0.44
5 M L 2 4 4 0.36
6 V H 4 5 4 0.34
7 L V 2 4 4 0.34
8 H M 0 2 2 0.30
9 H M 4 7 4 0.40
With the current implementation for Cao's method, row 0 is correctly identified as the point with maximal density and made the first centroid in the initialisation. However, the second and third initial centroids are also chosen as the first point in the set. ```python >>> from kmodes.kmodes import init_cao >>> X = vehicle_data.values >>> init_cao(X, 3) array([['H', 'M', 2, 2, 4], ['H', 'M', 2, 2, 4], ['H', 'M', 2, 2, 4]], dtype=object) ``` It follows from the statement of Cao's method that the point to be selected as the second centroid should have the maximal product of density and distance from our first centroid. Therefore, since there are no duplicate rows in our set, and the dissimilarity between any point and itself is zero, we should not see the same point chosen twice. In fact, if we look at the pairwise dissimilarity between all the points and our first centroid we see that rows 1, 2 and 6 have maximal dissimilarity (equal to 4), and of those rows - using our second table - we see that row 6 has maximal density. Hence, this is our second centroid. Now, we use a similar technique, following the statement of the algorithm, to find our third centroid. We must find which of our two centroids has minimal density * dissimilarity for each of our points, and then take the point in our set which has the maximal value of these minima. This point can be found by constructing a 2 x 10 matrix (indexed from 0) where the (i,j)th entry is the density of row i multiplied by the dissimilarity of row i with centroid j. This point corresponds to row 5. So, we should expect our centroids to be given by row 0, row 6 and row 5. My altered implementation of Cao's method (called `cao_method`) finds these centroids as expected: ```python >>> cao_method(X, 3) array([['H', 'M', 2, 2, 4], ['V', 'H', 4, 5, 4], ['M', 'L', 2, 4, 4]], dtype=object) ``` ### Performance As an addition to this, I believe that my implementation has led to a performance improvement since I do not rebuild the density-dissimilarity matrix (this is currently denoted as `dd`) for each cluster. Instead, I construct a new row when the next centroid is selected. ```python >>> %timeit init_cao(X, 3) 901 µs ± 12.1 µs per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 1000 loops each) >>> %timeit cao_method(X, 3) 183 µs ± 5.09 µs per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 10000 loops each) ``` This performance improvement is seen particularly as k increases. For instance, with the [zoo animal dataset](https://www.kaggle.com/uciml/zoo-animal-classification/), the performance improvement is rather substantial: ```python >>> df = pd.read_csv('../data/zoo,csv') >>> X = df[[col for col in df.columns if col not in ['animal_name', 'class_type']]].values >>> %timeit init_cao(X, 7) 2.23 s ± 59.6 ms per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 1 loop each) >>> %timeit cao_method(X, 7) 9.26 ms ± 141 µs per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 100 loops each) ``` I appreciate the time you've taken to read this issue, and hope that you are open to my suggestions. Of course, I am open to discussion about this topic and am eager to hear from you soon.

items.title: Is everything seeded?
items.body:
Whilst adding in some initialisation process I have been toying with, I've noticed that my results (and the results found with other initialisation methods) are not 100% reproducible. In scikit-learn's implementations, all classes, methods, etc. carry a `random_state` or seed for their random number generators so that results can be reproduced. This could make all the difference here since `np.argsort` (for instance) breaks ties at random. 

Could this feature be added so as to enhance the package, and fall in line with the `sklearn` standard?

Anyway, I've been trying to apply the algorithm to some data and plot the costs against the number of clusters like so:

```python
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from kmodes.kmodes import KModes
%matplotlib inline

data = pd.DataFrame({'BagColour': ['Blue', 'Blue', 'Red', 'Yellow', 'Green', 'Red'],
                     'Origin': ['JFK', 'HRW', 'NWK', 'BRM', 'GTW', 'JFK'],
                     'Row': ['A', 'A', 'C', 'D', 'B', 'A']
                    })

costs = []
for i in range(1, len(data)):
    km = KModes(n_clusters=i, n_init=50)
    clusters = km.fit_predict(data)
    costs.append(km.cost_)

plt.figure()
plt.plot(range(1, len(data)), costs)
plt.xlabel('Number of clusters')
plt.ylabel('Cost function');
```

items.title: Centroids output format
items.body:
Based on the results of running kprototypes on the stocks.csv file included in the examples, I have concluded that kprototypes.cluster_centroids_ represents the centroids in the following format:
    [array([cluster 0 centroid coordinates in numerical space],
              [cluster 1 centroid coordinates in numerical space], ...),
     array([cluster 0 centroid coordinates in categorical space],
              [cluster 1 centroid coordinates in categorical space], ...)]
where the i-th cluster centroid coordinates in either numerical or categorical space is of the form
    [x_i,0, x_i,1, ...]
where
    x_i,0 is the coordinate for the first (i.e. left-most) column of (categorical or numerical) data
    x_i,1 is the coordinate for the second (i.e. second left-most) column of (categorical or numerical) data
   ...
and where the j-th cluster centroid coordinate values in categorical space are elements of the set
    {0, 1, 2, ...}
where
    a value of 0 represents the category value whose name is first in alphabetical order
    a value of 1 represents the category value whose name is second in alphabetical order
    ...
i.e. the numerical values represent the mode (i.e. most frequently occurring) categorical value for the cluster, and where the numerical values shown are chosen by putting the category names in alphabetical order and representing the first name by 0, the second name by 1, etc.

Can you please tell me if my conclusions are correct? If there is documentation that describes all this, I apologize for this long-winded question, and I would greatly appreciate a pointer to that documentation.

Thank you very much.

items.title: Better handling of NaNs
items.body:
`np.unique` is used for encoding data values to integers. However, `numpy` currently treats every `np.NaN` as a unique value, creating many categories. (See: https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/2111)

Solution is to check with `np.isnan` so that we can just ignore all NaNs when encoding. The encoder then simply assigns all NaNs to the `-1` (i.e. "I don't know this value") category.
